content:
You are asking a very good question! While trees and shrubs may occupy some space that could be used for crops, farmers who practice agroforestry often employ various strategies to maximize the benefits of both the trees/shrubs and crops.

For example, they may plant crops in between rows of trees or shrubs, taking advantage of the space provided by the trees or shrubs while also benefiting from the shade and moisture retention provided by the trees. Alternatively, farmers may plant trees along field boundaries to create a windbreak or utilize marginal agricultural land, uncultivated land or degraded landscapes which are not suitable for crops.

Moreover, the crops that are grown under the canopy of trees (called agroforestry) are typically shade-tolerant, so they can grow well under the tree canopy and may even produce better yields than crops grown in full sun.

In addition to maximizing land use, farmers also choose tree species that provide a range of benefits such as food, fuel, and other products, which help support their livelihoods and diversify their income. By combining trees in different strengths with agriculture, land management can be adapted to local socio-economic and environmental situations.

Overall, the key to success in agroforestry is careful planning, management, and maintenance of the system to ensure that it is adapted to local conditions and that the farmers can create a balance. These balanced systems not only support agriculture but also conservation and restoration of biodiversity enabling long-term resilience, and productivity of agricultural land.
